case_title: MUHAMMAD ISMAIL vs GOVERNMENT OF BALOCHISTAN, through Secretary S&GA and others
reference_no_or_id: Service Appeals Nos.73, 88 of 2002, 2 to 5, 7, 9, 15 and 30 of 2003
case_number: Service Appeals Nos.73, 88 of 2002, 2 to 5, 7, 9, 15 and 30 of 2003
respondant: Government of Balochistan, through Secretary S&GA
respondents: Government of Balochistan, through Secretary S&GA
complaint_summary: Appellants challenged the legality of out-of-turn promotions granted to respondents 4 and 5, alleging violation of service laws and seniority rules.
investigation_summary: Respondents 4 and 5 were promoted based on their exceptional performance in apprehending high-profile criminals and dismantling a terrorist network. However, the promotions bypassed statutory rules and seniority considerations.
judgment_summary: The tribunal disapproved the out-of-turn promotions as arbitrary and against statutory rules. It directed the competent authority to reconsider seniority strictly in accordance with the law. Appeals were disposed of with no order as to costs.

decision_summary.time_barred: Delay in filing appeals was condoned due to public importance.
decision_summary.promotion_legality: Out of turn promotions were deemed unlawful as they violated statutory rules governing promotions.

Decision_or_verdict: Appeals disposed of; seniority to be reconsidered as per relevant rules.
legal_arguments: Promotion must adhere to seniority-cum-fitness criteria under service laws.
Out-of-turn promotions lack statutory basis in Police Rules, 1934.
Executive authority cannot arbitrarily grant promotions without Departmental Promotion Committee recommendations.
statutes: Civil Servants (Appointment, Promotion and Transfer) Rules, 1973
sections: Section 39(1) of Government of Balochistan Rules of Business
key_issues: Competence of executive authority in promotions

key_points.issue_1: Whether the appeals filed by the appellants are barred by time?
key_points.issue_2: Whether the Government/Executive Authority is competent to grant promotion, in recognition of meritorious services, to the officers of the police force, at the detriment of senior officers?

observations.promotion_rules: Promotion should be based on seniority-cum-fitness and through Departmental Promotion Committee.
observations.discretionary_powers: Discretionary powers must be exercised reasonably and not arbitrarily.
observations.reward_alternatives: Meritorious services should be rewarded with medals or commendations, not accelerated promotions.

directions.seniority_fixation: Competent authority directed to consider seniority of appellants and respondents strictly in accordance with law.
directions.future_objections: Any party may challenge the new seniority list before a competent forum.

additional_notes.appellants_promoted: All appellants except Tahir Allauddin were promoted to BPS-18 during the pendency of the appeals.
additional_notes.respondents_service: Respondents served over four years as Superintendent of Police in BPS-18.

maxims.Discretionary powers: Discretion must be exercised reasonably and not arbitrarily.

legal_terms.Out-of-turn promotion: Promotion granted bypassing standard seniority and fitness criteria.

words_and_phrases.Accelerated promotion: Promotion granted ahead of normal seniority progression.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the legality of out-of-turn promotions granted to two police officers, bypassing seniority rules. The tribunal disapproved the promotions and directed reconsideration of seniority in accordance with statutory rules.
